moves.1. e4: In this game I come out ahead by a big blunder by white.
moves.3. f4: This looks like a hybrid between the closed and grand prix variations.
moves.3... g6: Still aiming for control of the dark center squares and d4.
moves.4. Nf3: Knights before bishops is the general principle here.
moves.4... Bg7 5. d3: He abandons d4 for control of e4
moves.6. Be2 e6: Preventing his knight from occupying d5 as an outpost.
moves.7. Bd2 Nf6: I still have control of d4 now I develop my knight with no worries from pawn to e5
moves.8. O-O O-O 9. h4: His immediate kingside attack is met symetrically.
moves.9... h5 10. Ng5: A good outpost for white here as he aims for the h7 square.
moves.10... e5: Probably not a good move here since he can move Nd5
moves.11. Be3: He wants to grab my pawn on c5 with 12.fxe5 dxe5 13.Bxc5
moves.11... Nd4: I prevent him from doing this by establishing an outpost of my own.
moves.14. Nxe5: He takes the pawn as expected
moves.14... Bxe2: I threaten his Queen and Rook but not for long
moves.15. Nxe2 Nxe4: Instead of taking his knight I sac my knight to take his bishop.
moves.16. Nxd4: He takes my other knight and I take back with the pawn now I am threatening to take two of his bishops.
moves.16... cxd4 17. Nxg6: He sacs his knight to destroy my kingside.
moves.18... dxe3: And somehow ive won the exchange by taking his bishop very complicated position.
moves.19. Qe2: He wants to grab the e pawn.
moves.19... Qb6: I protect it and also have a direct diagonal to his King!
moves.20. b3: A gross blunder as he leaves his rook open for capture
moves.20... Bxa1 21. Rxa1 Rf2: White resigned here.  Notice he cannot stop the advance of the e pawn.

gameName: Looking to join Kings and Queens of the dungeon?
opening: Sicilian (B23), Grand Prix attack, Schofman variation
